ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about Canadian literature in the context of Canada's complex colonial (and postcolonial) history.
Ability to form connections between multiple historical eras and events, tracing themes through different racial experiences through colonial Canada
Over the course of the semester, I learned a variety of information regarding both the history and culture of Canada. In doing so,  I also developed my literature reading and analysis skills.
I learned a great deal about Canadian history and culture

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Obviously, Zoom presents certain limitations. But I really appreciated the range of readings and Professor Trumpener's broad knowledge of Canadian social and intellectual history.

Prof. Trumpener is extremely knowledgeable and open to our comments. The reading load is large, but not larger than most English courses. Meeting once a week can make the reading feel less urgent and less continuous than other courses. An overview of Canadian history/a timeline would be helpful to contextualize discussion before reading the pieces.

Strengths: Wide variety of texts with a range of topics
Weaknesses: some of the texts were long and uninteresting (but the Professor was open to feedback regarding the students' interest in the texts)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I'd recommend this course to any student interested in learning more about Canadian literature. There's a lot of great Canadian writing out there, much of which doesn't get much airtime in American schools. Taking this course exposed me to a lot of writers that I might otherwise have graduated without knowing.
Yes, I think it demonstrates the complexity of cultures that exist within what we may perceive as monolithic colonial cultures.
Yes, if you are interested in Canadian Literature or want to branch out of your normal interests, I would recommend this class.
